elements.content: Solvothermal and classical synthesis with an identical recipe involving 4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl acetic acid (HL1) and CdCl2 afforded two-dimensional (2D) (1) and one-dimensional (2) coordination polymers, respectively. Hexagonal plate-like crystals of [Cd2(L1)2Cl2] (1), which crystallize in the chiral orthorhombic space group (P212121), were obtained in high yield. The 1,2,4-triazole-4-yl acetate (L1) ligand, which has a significant kink in the spacer, leads to the formation of a CdII complex displaying a 2D single-stranded helical array. The pitch height of the helix is equal to the length of the crystallographic a axis (7.579 Å) which comprises two cadmium atoms and two ligands. Solid-state emission of 1 shows a strong emission band around 465 nm with photoexcitation at 290 nm. Mercury porosimetry measurements reveal pore size distribution with a diameter of 80, 10, and 1 μm. BET shows no preference for N2(g) but a low H2(g) adsorption of 4 cm3/g. Complex 1, which is constituted by a “soft” nonaromatic network that begins to collapse around 170 °C, was subjected to controlled pyrolysis to produce CdO with morphology and phase selectivity. Texture of the thus obtained pure cubic phase of CdO (β-form) was further tuned with the regulation of the annealing temperature. Crystals of rectangular blocks of [Cd(HL1L1)Cl]·2H2O (2), which were formed in small quantity, feature a centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group (P21/c). Their crystal structure reveals a one-dimensional linear chain where Cd atoms are connected by a triple bridge made up of one μ-chloride and two μ-N1,N2-1,2,4-triazole HL1 and L1. The coordination polymer charge is balanced by both chloride and the carboxylate group of L1.

elements.content:
Linear chains and a chiral helicate were successfully obtained through crystal engineering and slightly different reaction conditions using a derivatized amino acid building block.

Introduction

The perceptible appearance of amino acid derivatives in recent years either as metal-based molecular entities or oligomeric scaffolds in metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) are redolent of their inclusion in the synthon/tecton library. In this frame, the synthesis of CPs from natural products constitutes a new direction in the emerging field of MOFs. This includes nucleobases, peptides, magnesium formates, metal glutarates, γ-cyclodextrin, and amino acids. On the other hand, chiral amino acids are recognized to play a key role in supramolecular chemistry spin-offs such as, to name a few, intertwined catenanes, allosteric ionophores, etc.

Linear chains and a chiral helicate were successfully obtained through crystal engineering and slightly different reaction conditions using a derivatized amino acid building block.

Introduction

The perceptible appearance of amino acid derivatives in recent years either as metal-based molecular entities or oligomeric scaffolds in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) are redolent of their inclusion in the synthon/tecton library. In this frame, the synthesis of CPs from natural products constitutes a new direction in the emerging field of MOFs. This includes nucleobases, peptides, magnesium formates, metal glutarates, γ-cyclodextrin, and amino acids. On the other hand, chiral amino acids are recognized to play a key role in supramolecular chemistry spin-offs such as, to name a few, intertwined catenanes, allosteric ionophores, etc.

elements.content: With the rich inbuilt functional groups on their natural assorted framework that could be derivatized, amino acids offer intriguing topologies when inserted as building blocks in supramolecular hierarchical self-assemblies. Indeed, thanks to their genuine chirality (except glycine) and electronic asymmetry, amino acid derivatives are considered as a preeminent choice to introduce asymmetry into MOFs to direct the network construction. The nature of the spacer can also influence the network topology. In this frame, the structure and reactivity of different amino acids in their natural or derivatized forms were extensively studied. Relevant examples include proline, glycine, valine, alanine, aspartic acid, glutamic acid, a phenyl alanine, histidine, methionine, and typtophan.

elements.content: Applications envisioned in the majority of the above-mentioned cases are largely dependent on the molecular conformations that the precursors adopt during the self-assembly process in their CP/MOF as their conformation controls structure−function relationship. For instance, with ethyl 4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl-acetate as a template which was built from glycine, an Fe(II) one-dimensional (1D) spin crossover coordination polymer that acts as an “optical alert” at room temperature, was successfully designed. With the acid derivative of the same ligand, an unique three-dimensional (3D) porous nanoball Cu(II) network was also reported. The ability of 4-(methylthio)-2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)butanoic acid (HL2), which was built from methionine, to form Zn(II) complexes was exploited in a Zn-β-lactamases inhibition assay.

elements.content: The present work has been directed to make novel high dimensional networks containing Cd(II) with 4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl acetic acid (HL1, Scheme ). The impetus for using HL1 in the MOF design comes from its ability for spontaneous crystallization in a chiral, non-centrosymmetric space group despite its achiral origin. This versatile synthon is also polydentate by having N1,N2-coordination sites at one end with a carboxylate pincer at the other end, an ideal configuration for self-assembly. HL1 belongs to a family of flexible molecules having symmetric or asymmetric multidonor moieties, as found for instance for 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethane, 4,4′-bis(1,2,4-triazole), tetrazole-1-acetic acid, which are capable of bridging metal ions in infinite connectivity and were thus sought in crystal engineering as they favor self-assembly MOFs construction. Crystal structure determination of two Cd(II) CPs (1 and 2) was herein undertaken to navigate the self-assembly process, and N2(g) and H2(g) gas adsorption studies were performed. The possibility of using these complexes as “soft” sacrificial precursors to produce CdO with shape and phase selectivity is also described.

elements.content: Reaction of HL1 with CdCl2 in water afforded a white powder. Recrystallization with and without solvothermal treatment provided either large hexagonal crystals formulated as [Cd2(L1)2Cl2] (1) or rectangular blocks formulated as [Cd(HL1L1)Cl]·2H2O (2).
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis and Characterization

Reaction of HL1 with CdCl2 in water afforded a white powder. Recrystallization with and without solvothermal treatment provided either large hexagonal crystals formulated as [Cd2(L1)2Cl2] (1) or rectangular blocks formulated as [Cd(HL1L1)Cl]⋅2H2O (2).

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis qualitatively confirmed the morphology of microcrystals in bulk samples with that of millimeter sized crystals. Hexagonal plates 5−10 μm long in 1 and around 20 μm long thin blocks in 2 were observed (Figure ). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of 1 and 2 provide useful information about the coordination mode of 1,2,4-triazole and the carboxylic group to the metal (Figure ). The carboxylic group of HL1 shows two strong stretching vibrations corresponding to (-CO) and (C−O) at 1731 cm−1 and 1234 cm−1, respectively. These vibrations are almost unchanged in the FTIR spectrum of 2 (1739 cm−1 and 1234 cm−1) thus confirming the noninvolvement of the -CO group in coordination, whereas the (-CO) stretch vanishes in 1 together with the appearance of new broad bands around 1698 cm−1, thus confirming the involvement of carboxylate in coordination along with the triazole ring. For HL1, the band assigned to ring torsion of triazole at ν = 625 cm−1, the νCN stretching vibration at 1587 cm−1, and the N−N stretching band at ν = 1024 cm−1 are all slightly shifted upon complexation in 2 to ν = 630 cm−1, νCN = 1573 cm−1, and νN−N = 1042 cm−1, respectively. In 1, bands assigned to ring torsion of 1,2,4-triazole at ν = 628 cm−1, νCN = 1592 cm−1, and νN−N = 1033 cm−1 also confirm coordination to Cd(II). Electronic and luminescence spectra of HL1 and 1 were recorded on solid samples at 293 K. Diffuse reflectance spectra of HL1 show strong bands at 258 nm, with a shoulder at 294 nm, and are assigned to intraligand transitions (). They appear in 1 around the same region (252 nm, 290 nm) but with slightly reduced intensity which could be due to alteration of electron density in the ligand due to coordination. HL1 is weakly fluorescent. Emission spectra of 1 show a broad intense band around 465 nm with a shoulder at 492 nm when excited with 290 nm (), which was assigned to ligand to metal charge transfer transition. The thermal stability of 1 determined by TGA is relatively high. After an initial loss of moisture around 40 °C, the compound is stable until 170 °C and thereafter decomposes in four ill-defined steps (Figure e). Only some prominent peaks in experimental X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) of 1 match that of the simulated one from CIF file, which could be due to slight uptake of moisture by 1 resulting in a minor network reshuffle ().

elements.content: [Cd 2 (L1) 2 Cl 2 ] crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group P212121, with Z = 8. Crystallographic data are provided in Table , and a selection of bond lengths and angles is given in Table . Asymmetric unit is shown in Figure a. The self-assembling motif consists of two cadmium ions, five ligands, and three chloride ions. Although both cadmium ions share the same central core of CdN2O2Cl2, they differ in their bond distances and angles. Each Cd1 atom is coordinated by two bridging Cl atoms (Cd1−Cl2, 2.543(2) Å; Cd1−C1, 2.598(2) Å), two L1 molecules via the nitrogen atoms of the ring (Cd1−N6, 2.368(6) Å, Cd1−N2, 2.273(5) Å), and one L1 molecule via both O atoms of the carboxylate group (Cd1−O4, 2.274(4) Å; Cd1−O3, 2.516(4) Å) in a bidentate fashion (Figure a).

elements.content: The Cd2 has a similar environment with slight variation in the Cd2−N, Cd2−O, and Cd2−Cl bond distances (Table ). The single μ-N1,N2-triazole and μ-Cl bridging hold the neighboring cadmium atoms at a distance of Cd···Cd = 4.101 Å, whereas across the full length of ligand the Cd···Cd distance is 8.907 Å. The homo cis angles CdN2, CdO2, and CdCl2 around each central Cd atoms adopt mutually perpendicular conformations (Figure b). This pattern of a dissimilar environment around each Cd1(a) and Cd2(b) propagates in abbaab order along the chain in the c direction. This simultaneous use of 1,2,4-triazole and carboxylic groups in coordination with cadmium ions in a self-assembly process leads to a two-dimensional (2D) network. The dihedral angle between 1,2,4-triazole plane and -CH2COO¯ planes connected to Cd1 (C6−N5−C7−C8) is 80.72°, whereas across Cd2 (C4−C3−N3−C2) it is 114.0°, which is significantly larger than the value found for the free ligand HL1. An overview of the crystallographic parameters of related compounds is given in Table . Navigation along the different planes of this structure reveals that this 2D network has a spiral connectivity leading to helicates. The propagating chains running along the a axis (Figure ) are made up of head to tail coordinated L1 molecules connecting Cd1 atoms to form a helical chain. The resulting intrinsically spontaneous helicity reveals a skeletal structure with a single-stranded helix consisting of ligand and cadmium in each turn. Only two cadmium and two ligands span one helical turn so that the helix is considerably compressed. The pitch height of the helix is equal to the length of the crystallographic a axis (7.579 Å). Helical arrangement implicitly results in chirality producing right- (Δ = P) or left-handed (Λ = M) helicity around a principal axes. The cylindrical helices are arranged in an alternating right-handed and left-handed fashion in the intrachain “a” direction with a distance of 10.3 Å (Figure ), which are domains of opposite helicity. Thus, the complex is racemic because the right- and left-handed chains are alternatively arranged, but in the b direction it shows single handedness. The helical twist of the strand results from the torsion between the 1,2,4-triazole plane and the spacer connecting the chelating carboxylic group. The orientation of the -CH2 (winged, (w) or pinched, (p)) is crucial to direct the spirality. Both the -CH2 of each turn adopt a favorable winged orientation. This spiral “staircase” leaves behind a roughly polygonal cavity of 4.89 Å (O3−O3) × 6.224 Å (C7−C7). Helicity has been earlier noticed on a few 1,2,4-triazole CPs. Indeed, in a related system constructed from 3-amino-1,2,4-triazolate, where additionally cadmium ions are bridged by bromide ions, two kinds of helical channels with opposite chirality were observed. With 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, a Cd(II) coordination framework with 2D helical channel was also recently reported.

The helical twist of the strand results from the torsion between the 1,2,4-triazole plane and the spacer connecting the chelating carboxylic group. The orientation of the -CH2  (winged, (w) or pinched, (p)) is crucial to direct the spirality. Both the -CH2 of each turn adopt a favorable winged orientation. This spiral "staircase" leaves behind a roughly polygonal cavity of 4.89 Å (O3-O3) × 6.224 Å (C7-C7). Helicity has been earlier noticed on a few 1,2,4-triazole CPs. Indeed, in a related system constructed from 3-amino-1,2,4-triazolate, where additionally cadmium ions are bridged by bromide ions, two kinds of helical channels with opposite chirality were observed. With 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, a Cd(II) coordination framework with 2D helical channel was also recently reported.

elements.content: [Cd(HL1L1)Cl]·2H 2 O (2) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, with Z = 4. Crystallographic data are provided in Table , and a selection of bond lengths and angles are given in Table . The asymmetric unit of 2 is shown in Figure a. Each Cd atom is coordinated by two chloride atoms (Cd−Cl, 2.656(1), 2.616(6) Å), in axial position and four nitrogen atoms (Cd−N1, 2.343(3) Å, Cd−N2, 2.312(3) Å, Cd−N4, 2.374(3) Å, and Cd−N5, 2.339(3) Å) belonging to four different ligands forming the equatorial plane, thus completing an octahedral geometry. The elongation in the axial direction is evident from the bond lengths. The triple bridge that is made up of one μ-chloride and two μ-N1,N2-1,2,4-triazole of different L1/HL1 (Figure b) connect neighboring cadmium centers leading to a 1D coordination polymer with a Cd···Cd distance of 3.845 Å. The 1,2,4-triazole rings of L1 are fairly planar; the deviation from the least-squares plane through the ring atoms is smaller than 0.02(1) Å. There are number of interesting similar Cd MOFs of 1,2,4-triazole derivatives. Lu et al. reported a series of Cd coordination compounds ranging from 0 to 3D thanks to substitution of the 1,2,4-triazole or variation of the anion.

elements.content: In a coligand modulated Cd-1,2,4-triazolate framework, tri- and pentacadmium clusters were reported with a slightly longer Cd···Cd distance (4.049 Å) than for 2. Interesting cases of μ-OH2 bridged 3,5-disubstituted 1,2,4-triazole systems and polymer chains containing μ3-Cl were also reported. It is worth mentioning too the series of 3D Cd-triazolate complexes involving anions such as F−, Cl−, Br−, I−, NO3 −, SO4 2− which show diversity in coordination. What makes 2 unique is related to the dual contribution of its ligand system. Indeed, HL1/L1 not only acts as a bridging ligand but also as anion due the presence of a deprotonated carboxylate group. Interestingly, the carboxylic group is kept away from the coordination sphere, a crucial point for the design of 1D coordination polymer involving switchable iron(II) spin crossover centers with a MN6 core. The ligands in the 1D chain are arranged in zigzag fashion along the a direction (Figure ). The three planes containing ligands are mutually perpendicular around cadmium ions and are threaded by μ-Cl anions as intersecting points. It was difficult to locate the hydrogen atoms in structure refinement on the carboxylic group of the ligand, but a comparison of bond length of -C-O and -CO between ligands contributing to the two planes with that of free HL1 gave evidence of deprotonation. In the free ligand, the -CO distance is 1.215(3) Å, and the −C−O− bond length is 1.307(2) Å. It is interesting to note that the ligand exhibiting a dual nature forms an exclusively separate plane (Figure b, plane colored in pink) with shortened C(4)−O(1) = 1.255(5) Å and C(4)−O(2) = 1.251(4) Å distances, which indicate a resonance double bond nature as a result of deprotonation. The ligand molecule in the other plane shows bond lengths of C8−O3 = 1.306(4) and C8−O4 = 1.206(4) Å similar to free ligand. The consequence of the dual nature of the ligand, which exists in both protonated and deprotonated in the crystal structure of 2 can also be seen in the different bond angles, bond lengths, and dihedral angles (Table ). Although the environment around both Cd atoms is the same, there is a change in bond angles and distances. Chloride forms two unequal bonds with cadmium, and all the Cd−N bond lengths are different as indicated above. Thus, the CdN4Cl2 octahedron is distorted with a distortion parameter of Σ = 20.44°. The opposite μ-N1,N2-triazole rings bridging two Cd atoms are different with respect to bond angles and distances within them and with cadmium. The tail ends bearing carboxylic groups of the ligands of one plane forming this 1D network face in the same direction. Similarly, this region is also shared by a plane from neighboring chain creating a super hydrophilic region (Figure ). The formation of triple μ-N1,N2-triazole bridging, as found for instance for [Cu(hyetrz)3](CF3SO3)2·H2O, or double chloro bridges plus a single μ-N1, N2-triazole bridging, was not favored in this network, due to the possibility for the ligand to act as monoanionic. A significant deviation of planes containing the carboxylic group with respect to the triazole planes in L1 of 1 was noted. In HL1, these planes are orthogonal, but in 2 they deviate by nearly 21° (torsion angle (ø), C2−N3−C3−C4, 69.13°) and 25° (ø, C5−N6−C7−C8, 65.40°). This deviation is not only due to sterical reasons but also to secondary interactions in the super hydrophilic region. The hydrophilic region is rich in hydrogen bonds, the lattice water molecules being the epicenters of the H-bonding network. Carboxylic groups also greatly contribute to favor a dense H-bonding network. The lattice water molecule which is absent in 1, forms two H-bonds with the carboxylic groups of different 1,2,4-triazoles from different planes (C4−O2···O6, 2.751 Å with an angle C4−O2−O6 of 105.08° and C8−O3···O6, 2.568 Å and an angle of C8−O3−O6 of 119.25°). The deprotonated ligand forms additional H-bonds; one with 2.764 Å (O1···H(O5)) with lattice water which in turn forms an H-bond with the chloride bridge (Cl···H(O5), 3.228 Å). As a consequence, the bond angle of 122.64° for -COO− in the free ligand is stretched out to 127.02° in the complex. The CH2 spacer is also involved in H-bonding with lattice water molecules with 2.628 Å (C3(H3A)···O1). The proton on the triazole ring C6(H6)···O5 forms a strong H-bond with 2.242 Å. Interestingly, the bridging mode of two ligands and one chloride around two Cd atoms create a bicyclo seven-membered metallomacrocycle ring. This 1D coordination network is totally different from the 2D helical structure in 1 despite sharing the same components, thus indicating the role of reaction conditions in the self-assembly process.

elements.content: Channels found in the crystal structure of 1 prompted us to investigate gas adsorption capacities and to measure porosity partitioning. A gas sorption study for 1 was carried out using N2(g) and H2(g). Before measurements, the crystalline sample was vacuumed at room temperature (r.t.) in order to remove surface moisture which was observed by TGA analysis (Figure e). Within the relative pressure range investigated, N2(g) adsorption measurements did not show any significant uptake, but a low irreversible H2(g) uptake of 4 cm3/g could be detected. This difference in adsorption properties could be due to size difference of adsorbing gases or simply to a low surface adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Studies of 1 

Channels found in the crystal structure of 1 prompted us to investigate gas adsorption capacities and to measure porosity partitioning. A gas sorption study for 1 was carried out using N2(g) and H2(g). Before measurements, the crystalline sample was vacuumed at room temperature (r.t.) in order to remove surface moisture which was observed by TGA analysis (Figure e). Within the relative pressure range investigated, N2(g) adsorption measurements did not show any significant uptake, but a low irreversible H2(g) uptake of 4 cm3/g could be detected. This difference in adsorption properties could be due to size difference of adsorbing gases or simply to a low surface adsorption.

elements.content: “Porosity partitioning” in 1 was also investigated by Hg intrusion porosimetry (MIP). Both techniques of gas adsorption and MIP rely upon balances between surface tension forces, capillary forces, and pressure, but their outcome may not be comparable due to distinctly different physical interactions involved in the two methods. Intrusion curve and the corresponding pore size distribution are displayed in Figure , which shows the volume of intruded Hg as a function of applied pressure. We recall that pressure is inversely proportional to the pore size according to Washburn equation (high pressures being necessary to fill small pores by inverted capillary effect). Mercury fills largest pores first, entering the smallest pores last under high pressure unlike gas adsorption. Analysis of Figure allows identification of three steps. Indeed, as the pressure is gradually increased and as soon as it corresponds to a pore size, Hg enters the pores and a new step is recorded. When considering the pore size distribution (by applying the Washburn equation assuming constant contact angle and surface tension), the recorded steps can be understood as follows: the step between 1 and 5 psi corresponds to pores centered at ∼80 μm, between 10 and 50 psi to pores of ∼7000 nm, and a hardly visible step between 60 and 200 psi to pores of ∼1000 nm. All of these pores would originate from interparticular porosity, which is also in accordance with the SEM observations that reveal nonporous crystals (Figure a). After that, the curve reaches a plateau indicating that there are no smaller pores present. Earlier in the nanoporous Cu(II) network based on the same ligand, we could observed pores of diameter 50 μm, 6000 nm, 2000 nm which were assigned to interparticular porosity, whereas pores of 350 nm diameter were traced by SEM. These results illustrate the usefulness of Hg porosimetry for a complete porosity characterization of such coordination polymers.

elements.content: In material sciences, metal threaded “soft” nonaromatic networks like 1 give tangible perception for facile generation of oxide material upon controlled breakdown of their network. Such methods where surface energy and growth kinetics can be fine-tuned offer tailoring architecture of nano- and microcrystals oxide. Various synthetic methods were explored to prepare cadmium oxides owing to their shape- and size-dependent technological applications such as photovoltaic cells, gas sensors, transparent conductive oxides, phototransistors, photodiodes, transparent electrodes, in the form of rods and wires, whiskers, disk, cubes, belts, most of which are based on physical and chemical technique such as sol−gel, spray pyrolysis, sputtering method, Langmuir−Blodgett deposition, solvothermal synthesis, and controlled decomposition of MOF. TGA of 1 (Figure e) provides an overview of thermal stability and decomposition patterns. After the initial weight loss around 45 °C, which is due to surface moisture, the compound was stable until 170 °C and then decomposed into three ill-defined broad steps from 200 to 900 °C. At 850 °C a complete destruction of the ligand framework is evidenced. In a typical pyrolysis procedure, 1 was heated at a rate of 10 °C/min until 850 °C and allowed to rapidly cool to r.t., which led to isolation of a white residue. SEM images (Figure a) on this residue showed the presence of nearly cubic rods with thickness of 800 nm. The poor quality of the XRPD pattern did not allow us to assign it to any known phase. As mild sputtering was frequently observed with this procedure, the isolation of sufficient quantity of residue was difficult. This led us to use a mild thermal treatment of 1 °C/min until 850 °C instead, followed by rapid cooling to r.t. The obtained reddish-brown residue was considered for further investigation for phase identification, purity, and morphological characterization. The XRPD pattern shown in Figure f was indexed to the powder pattern of the pure cubic phase of CdO (β-form) (JCPDS file No. 05-0640). The diffractogram shows prominent peaks at 2θ(°) = 32.99, 38.29, 55.27, 65.94, 69.26, which are associated with (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes, respectively. It clearly shows that CdO crystallizes in rock-salt cubic structure. The pattern does not reveal any other peaks thereby confirming excellent phase purity. SEM images of this oxide (Figure b) shows truncated octahedron shaped crystals of 1−2 μm size. The shaping of these oxides can be further tuned and the same results of phase purity (based on XRPD pattern) were observed for the reddish brown residue obtained when pyrolysis was extended up to 850 or 900 °C, and subsequently allowed to be slowly cooled to r.t. In the former case, hexagonal blocks were obtained (Figure c), whereas a treatment at 900 °C afforded well-defined octahedral crystals (Figure d), both of them in the range of 1−2 μm.

elements.content: Amine derivatization in amino acids provides natural and ideal topology having synchronized conformational orientations of two relevant potential coordinating functional groups, namely, carboxylic and triazole moieties on the same framework. Present work justifies that 1,2,4-triazole functionalized amino acids/esters would find their niche in the design of functional MOFs. A prominent feature of this work is the spontaneous helicity observed in 1 due to the hierarchical self-assembly of the tiny synthon HL1 originating in non-centrosymmetric space group. Although the use of chiral molecules is the most common strategy for obtaining products with a non-centrosymmetric arrangement in the crystal lattice, it is not a rule. It is found that only 10−15% of achiral organic molecules crystallize in non-centrosymmetric space groups. In contrast to the chiral amino acids, nonchiral glycine (as a structural unit) cannot enforce non-centrosymmetry of a crystal structure. But its electronic and structural asymmetry together with consolidated effort of noncovalent interactions with suitable metal ions as connectors may lead to crystallization in a non-centrosymmetric space group. By using bridging ligands with a significant kink in the topology instead of linear rigid molecules, the formation of networks with a lower symmetry and helicity is possible. The simple torsion angle count around the spacer in such molecules forms the basis of the assessment of molecular flexibility in them. Such conformationally flexible backbone and electronic asymmetry (push−pull effect) have high chances of ending up in non-centrosymmetrica space group, and such compounds have an enormous significance because of technological properties such as single harmonic generator (SHG), piezo-pyro-ferro electricity, triboluminescence. On the other hand 2, which forms a linear 1D chain despite sharing same synthetic recipe, has a origin in the centrosymmetric space group and would provide logistics for the design of 1D spin crossover polymers. Finally, we have also shown that these CPs could be a suitable host to carve the desired metal oxides with shape and phase selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

Amine derivatization in amino acids provides natural and ideal topology having synchronized conformational orientations of two relevant potential coordinating functional groups, namely, carboxylic and triazole moieties on the same framework. Present work justifies that 1,2,4-triazole functionalized amino acids/esters would find their niche in the design of functional MOFs. A prominent feature of this work is the spontaneous helicity observed in 1 due to the hierarchical self-assembly of the tiny synthon HL1 originating in non-centrosymmetric space group. Although the use of chiral molecules is the most common strategy for obtaining products with a non-centrosymmetric arrangement in the crystal lattice, it is not a rule. It is found that only 10-15% of achiral organic molecules crystallize in non-centrosymmetric space groups. In contrast to the chiral amino acids, nonchiral glycine (as a structural unit) cannot enforce non-centrosymmetry of a crystal structure. But its electronic and structural asymmetry together with consolidated effort of noncovalent interactions with suitable metal ions as connectors may lead to crystallization in a non-centrosymmetric space group. By using bridging ligands with a significant kink in the topology instead of linear rigid molecules, the formation of networks with a lower symmetry and helicity is possible. The simple torsion angle count around the spacer in such molecules forms the basis of the assessment of molecular flexibility in them. Such conformationally flexible backbone and electronic asymmetry (push-pull effect) have high chances of ending up in non-centrosymmetrica space group, and such compounds have an enormous significance because of technological properties such as single harmonic generator (SHG), piezo-pyro-ferro electricity, triboluminescence. On the other hand 2, which forms a linear 1D chain despite sharing same synthetic recipe, has a origin in the centrosymmetric space group and would provide logistics for the design of 1D spin crossover polymers. Finally, we have also shown that these CPs could be a suitable host to carve the desired metal oxides with shape and phase selectivity.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial sources: benzene, N,N-dimethylformamide (Sigma-Aldrich), glycine ethyl ester hydrochloride, thionyl chloride (Acros), aq. hydrazine hydrate (Aldrich), and cadmium chloride (UCB). 4H-1,2,4-Triazol-4-yl acetic acid (HL1) was prepared following our reported method.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (3 mL) of CdCl2 (0.036 g, 0.196 mmol) was added dropwise to an aqueous solution (2 mL) of HL1 (0.05 g, 0.393 mmol) affording a white precipitate. After 30 min of efficient stirring at room temperature, the white precipitate was transferred with dried methanol (2 mL) into a Teflon-lined cylindrical stainless steel chamber of capacity 25 mL. The closed chamber was then placed inside a preheated box furnace at 150 °C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, a colorless solution was obtained which after evaporation of the solvent afforded colorless hexagonal plates single crystals within a day (1). Yield: 34 mg. 35%. Anal. Calcd. for C4H4N3O2ClCd (1) C, 17.54; H, 1.47; N, 15.34%. Found: C, 17.18; H, 2.14; N 14.92%. FTIR (KBr disk, cm−1): 3468br, 3120s, 1698w, 1649sh, 1592s, 1412 m, 1315 m, 1033s, 628 m. Diffuse reflectance spectrum (λmax, nm, vs PTFE): 260, 290. In the absence of solvothermal treatment, the white precipitate obtained upon recrystallization from hot aq. MeOH afforded few rectangular colorless blocks (2). FTIR (KBr disk, cm−1): 3360br, 1739s, 1618 m, 1573 m, 1385 m, 1234s, 1042 m, 625 m. Because of their low yield, no further analysis was carried out except single crystal structure determination.

elements.content: 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 300 and 75 MHz on a Bruker AC300 instrument. The residual solvent peak was used as internal reference. FTIR spectra were recorded on a FTIR-8400S SHIMADZU spectrophotometer using KBr discs. CHN analyses were performed at the University College London (UK). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5000 counter diffractometer working with a Kα radiation (1.5418 Å) at 293 K. TGA-DTA analyses were performed in air either at a heating rate of 10 K/min (298 to 1173 K) or 1 K/min (298 to 423 K) using an Universal V2.5H TA Instruments. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were performed with a Gemini Digital Scanning Microscope 982 with 1 kV accelerating voltage using an aluminum sample holder. Solid state emission spectra were recorded on a Fluorolog-3 spectrometer at r.t. The gas adsorption study for 1 was carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP2010 porosimeter. Prior to analyses and in order to remove eventual surface adsorbed/coated moisture after synthesis, about 100 mg of fresh crystals was outgassed under a dynamic vacuum at r.t. Both N2(g) and H2(g) adsorption−desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K in a relative pressure range from 0.001 to 0.995 psi (with respect to N2(g)). The same samples were subjected to Hg porosimetry measurements using a Micromeritics Autopore IV. A penetrometer with an appropriate stem volume was chosen in order to record Hg intrusion. Prior to analysis, the sample was evacuated at r.t. and Hg was then forced into the sample under pressure up to 30000 psi (corresponding to a minimum pore size of 6 nm according to the Washburn equation.). Pyrolysis of cadmium complexes were performed either in TGA apparatus or within a temperature programmable oven (Carbolite Furnaces). Samples were normally heated to 850−900 °C in ceramic crucibles or ceramic Petri dishes.

Solid state emission spectra were recorded on a Fluorolog-3 spectrometer at r.t. The gas adsorption study for 1 was carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP2010 porosimeter. elements.content: Caution: (a) All synthetic operations concerned with benzene which is a possible carcinogen, should be carried out in efficient fume hood. (b) During pyrolysis of 1, a mild explosion can occur if the sample is packed tightly in the holder.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 2 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. A transparent crystal was selected from the reaction product and mounted with epoxy glue onto a glass capillary. The measurement was carried out at 293 K using a STOE IPDS diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation. The exposure time was 10 s per frame, and the crystal-detector distance was 60 mm. Data reduction and analytical absorption correction were performed using the X-Area software suite. The final lattice parameters were calculated from all reflections observed in the actual data collection. Systematic absences indicated the space groups P212121 for 1 and P21/c for 2. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR 2004, which revealed the atomic positions, and refined by using the SHELX-97 program package. The final refinements were carried out on F o 2. Atomic scattering factors for spherical neutral free atoms were taken from standard sources, and anomalous dispersion corrections were applied. Final R indices for 1: R 1 = 0.0325, wR 2 = 0.0850 for [I > 2σ(I)] and R 1 = 0.0461, wR 2 = 0.1049 for all data. Final R indices for 2: R 1 = 0.0436, wR 2 = 0.1134 for [I > 2σ(I)] and R 1 = 0.0548, wR 2 = 0.1187 for all data.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Analyses

The structures of 1 and 2 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. A transparent crystal was selected from the reaction product and mounted with epoxy glue onto a glass capillary. The measurement was carried out at 293 K using a STOE IPDS diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation. The exposure time was 10 s per frame, and the crystal-detector distance was 60 mm. Data reduction and analytical absorption correction were performed using the X-Area software suite. The final lattice parameters were calculated from all reflections observed in the actual data collection. Systematic absences indicated the space groups P212121 for 1 and P21/c for 2. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR 2004, which revealed the atomic positions, and refined by using the SHELX-97 program package. The final refinements were carried out on F o 2. Atomic scattering factors for spherical neutral free atoms were taken from standard sources, and anomalous dispersion corrections were applied. Final R indices for 1: R 1 = 0.0325, wR 2 = 0.0850 for [I > 2σ(I)] and R 1 = 0.0461, wR 2 = 0.1049 for all data. Final R indices for 2: R 1 = 0.0436, wR 2 = 0.1134 for [I > 2σ(I)] and R 1 = 0.0548, wR 2 = 0.1187 for all data.
